alert.note: Alert for Cumberland; York (Pennsylvania) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued January 10 at 3:26AM EST until January 11 at 5:00AM EST by NWS State College
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following creeks in Pennsylvania... Aughwick Creek at Shirleysburg affecting Huntingdon County. Yellow Breeches Creek near Camp Hill affecting York and Cumberland Counties. Swatara Creek at Harper Tavern affecting Schuylkill and Lebanon Counties. Swatara Creek near Hershey affecting Lebanon and Dauphin Counties. ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following creeks in Pennsylvania... Sherman Creek at Shermans Dale affecting Perry County. For the Aughwick Creek...including Shirleysburg...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Sherman Creek...including Shermans Dale...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Yellow Breeches Creek...including Camp Hill...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Swatara Creek...including Harper Tavern, Hershey...Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL LATE TONIGHT... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Yellow Breeches Creek near Camp Hill. * WHEN...Until late tonight. * IMPACTS...At 7.0 feet, Low lying areas in the Green Lane Farms development on the right bank of Yellow Breeches Creek begin to flood. A mobile home park near Williams Grove is also affected by high water. At 9.0 feet, A number of homes in the Green Lane Farms development are affected by high water. Cedar Cliff Drive on the left bank upstream from the single span bridge on Green Lane Drive is inundated. Creekwood Drive has several feet of water on it, and water is approaching homes. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 2:45 AM EST Wednesday the stage was 7.9 feet. - Forecast...The creek is expected to rise to a crest of 8.2 feet this morning. It will then fall below flood stage late this evening. - Flood stage is 7.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued later this morning.
